The solid state usb devices should probably crash over time.

topic.title: Linux Closing Zeronet using ctrl-c may cause a user blowout if sites are being updated.
topic.body:
Linux Closing Zeronet using ctrl-c in terminal may cause a user blowout if sites are being updated at that time. 
I have been able to duplicate this problem 3 times so far and it looks like the only way to shut down Zeronet safely
is to do on the zeronet pull down menu and select shut down zeronet. 
This possible bug needs to be cross checked for duplicated results. 
WARNING!: BACK UP ZERONET COMPLETELY BEFORE TESTING THIS!

Please post comments on this issue.  Have you had the same problem?

I tested this out on a 64 gig thumdrive. Zeronet ate it in about 3 months. The amount of data reading and writing tends to destroy them. Feel free to test it. I recommend  backing up Zeronet totally on a platter drive. 
Always expect it to fail. Your usage may very.  However for a short term usage it would probably be fine. Those transistor layers die over usage time unfortunately.

> [shitchell](#comment_84_1LybGoL99LBuYE8ZtwgJC8dxkii3UmYKpo): Shit... o_o that seems like kind of a bad thing, no? How many users are going to think to put their zeronet data folder on a drive other than their hard drive? Good to know, though, I guess...

I paid $11.99 usd for a 64 gig drive on clearance. I did not expect it to do very well. This technology will get better over time. If you get a very expensive thumdrive that has lots of transistor layers on the chip. I am sure you will get a longer duration of use over time. SSD Drives unfortunately do not fully replace the platter drives for long term use and storage. If anyone has had any better results please let me know. Just remember that your portion of Zeronet may be the only one out there. So data loss effects Zeronet p2p stored data on the network as a whole collective.

> [styromaniac@kxoid.bit](#comment_48_1PxcegJ1mKoMHeS73f9MvXeUWDq8BdnSv3): I recommend SDXC cards by Pro Grade, in case anyone needed to know. They're the fastest and tested for reliability, the best binned cards. I don't think there's anything faster. That's going based on my internet research.

Get one and test it. Real world hardware testing is the only way to go.

> [shitchell](#comment_85_1LybGoL99LBuYE8ZtwgJC8dxkii3UmYKpo): Would you recommend keeping your data files on a flash drive or other media besides your computer's hard drive?

Always have a separate drive to back up your data. It will save you from those oops moments. Or an out right crash. Anything can take out a computer and no data is ever safe. Unless it is in printed form. I still use a typewriter for critical data storage. Old school is the best school.

> [shitchell](#comment_86_1LybGoL99LBuYE8ZtwgJC8dxkii3UmYKpo): I have a 1 TB external HD for my backups :p I was just wondering, since you said ZeroNet does a ton of read/writes and is killer on flash drives, if it'd be better to store my data off of my HD for its safety :p

I think you can do it either way as long as your usb does not crash on you. I would run a working zeronet on your local drive and a backup on the usb. You can switch it up and see if there is any performance issues. It would be faster on your local drive. I am assuming that your external drive is a platter drive. If it is an ssd usb then I would only use it for a backup. SSD drives are still new and real world long term storage has not been fully tested. It has only been simulated/tested on read writes to the drives. Usb platter drives are dirt cheap now days. As long as you dont drop them or shake them when they are on they are a good option.

I am also using a 1TB Samsung ssd. They are supposedly the best. However I have seen lots of drive failure videos with testing them to maximum usage levels. We are all new to this technology. I hope they last, however I am very skeptical that they will last more than 10 years. Platter drives are good if you don't drop them or bang them around when they are on. I think that optical drives will have a return. Everything in computer science is recycled designs that are built on years later because we pushed the designs to there maximum cost usage limit. Some day punch cards will return in a new format. Until then back up everything.
